column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity|identifier|value
#Text=The dual role of coherent twin boundaries in hydrogen embrittlement
#Text=Hydrogen embrittlement (HE) causes engineering alloys to fracture unexpectedly, often at considerable economic or environmental cost.
#Text=Inaccurate predictions of component lifetimes arise from inadequate understanding of how alloy microstructure affects HE.
#Text=Here we investigate hydrogen-assisted fracture of a Ni-base superalloy and identify coherent twin boundaries (CTBs) as the microstructural features most susceptible to crack initiation.
#Text=This is a surprising result considering the renowned beneficial effect of CTBs on mechanical strength and corrosion resistance of many engineering alloys.

#Text=Remarkably, we also find that CTBs are resistant to crack propagation, implying that hydrogen-assisted crack initiation and propagation are governed by distinct physical mechanisms in Ni-base alloys.
#Text=This finding motivates a re-evaluation of current lifetime models in light of the dual role of CTBs.
#Text=It also indicates new paths to designing materials with HE-resistant microstructures.

#Text=U ptake of hydrogen (H) can cause engineering alloys to lose their ductility and fracture unexpectedly$^{1}$. This deleterious phenomenon, known as hydrogen embrittlement (HE), disrupts power generation, H containment and hydrocarbon extraction$^{2-4}$. High-strength alloys subjected to HE in extreme environments, such as deep oil wells, are often poorly accessible and difficult to monitor, forcing reliance on conservative lifetime limits to prevent catastrophic failures$^{5,6}$. Inadequate understanding of how alloy microstructure affects HE hampers higher-fidelity component lifetime predictions.
#Text=Coherent twin boundaries (CTBs) are often thought to be inherently resistant to HE because of their high surface separation energy and low H solubility$^{7,8}$.

#Text=However, we show that in Inconel 725-an advanced nickel (Ni)-base alloy developed specifically for extreme environments$^{9}$-cracks preferentially initiate at S 3 CTBs, yet at the same time are unlikely to propagate along them.

#Text=By elucidating the surprising dual role of S 3 boundaries in HE, our work demonstrates that H-assisted crack initiation and propagation are governed by distinct physical mechanisms in this alloy system.
#Text=This finding opens new paths to improved failure prediction and to design of HE-resistant materials.
#Text=Mechanical testing of hydrogen embrittled samples.
#Text=We conducted in situ tensile tests on H-charged samples of Inconel 725 in a scanning electron microscope (SEM; see Methods).

#Text=The samples were prepared with different thicknesses: a thin sample (30 m m) that contains mostly through-thickness grains and a thicker sample (45 m m) where most grains do not extend through the sample thickness.
#Text=No evidence of intergranular fracture was observed in samples that were not charged with H: failure in them was ductile-transgranular and occurred after onset of necking (Supplementary Fig. 1).
#Text=By contrast, H-charged samples did not neck and exhibited a mixture of ductile transgranular and brittlelike intergranular fracture, as shown in Fig.

#Text=Such behaviour is common in HE of face-centred cubic (FCC) metals, such as Ni and Ni-base alloys$^{10,11}$. In the thicker sample, we observed a large number of intergranular secondary cracks in addition to the main crack (Fig. 1a).
#Text=These secondary cracks enabled us to pinpoint the microstructural features responsible for crack initiation and propagation.
#Text=Secondary crack analysis.
#Text=To distinguish between crack initiation and propagation sites, we classify all secondary cracks as 'singlegrain boundary (GB) cracks' or 'multi-GB cracks,' based on the
#Text=number of cracked GBs they contain.
#Text=Single-GB cracks contain just one partially or fully cracked GB, as illustrated in Fig.
#Text=2a-c, and may terminate in a short intragranular crack.

#Text=Dark regions in the electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) map represent areas with insufficient signal to determine grain orientation, due either to lack of material in the case of cracks or to surface contamination resulting from sample handling.

#Text=As there are no pre-existing cracks in our samples and H-assisted cracks initiate at the sample surface$^{12}$, the GBs in the single-GB cracks are identified as preferential crack initiation sites.
#Text=We consider crack initiation to encompass the nucleation and initial growth of a crack along a single GB, and initiation sites to be the microstructural features at which this occurs.

#Text=We do not find any intergranular crack initiation at or propagation through brittle m m-scale carbides (Supplementary Fig. 2), in contrast to previous observations in steel$^{13}$, nor do we find cracks initiating along slip bands, as observed in iron-based superalloys$^{14}$.
#Text=After initiation, intergranular cracks may propagate along adjacent GBs and thus become multi-GB cracks, as shown in Fig.
#Text=2d-f. From these cracks, we determine which GBs are especially susceptible to crack propagation.
#Text=Finally, we also investigate the character of non-cracked GBs connected to the ends of single-and multi-GB cracks.
#Text=These GBs are likely to be crack propagation resistant, as cracks adjacent to them did not propagate along them.
#Text=H-assisted fracture susceptibility of different GB types.
#Text=W e characterized all GBs of interest, cracked and non-cracked, by correlating SEM images with EBSD data (see Methods).
#Text=GBs were classified based on their S value, which is a measure of misorientation in coincidence site lattice theory$^{15}$.
#Text=GBs with S = 1-29 are labelled as 'low-S ' and all others as 'general.'
#Text=Among low-S GBs, we call particular attention to S 3 CTBs because they are often thought to improve mechanical strength and resistance to stress corrosion cracking in metal alloys$^{16}$.
#Text=These qualities stem from the especially low energy of S 3 CTBs,
#Text=Figure 1 | Post-mortem EBSD analysis of H-charged Inconel 725.
#Text=(a) EBSD maps superimposed on SEM micrographs from a 45m m-thick sample loaded to failure in tension showing both the main crack and several secondary cracks (identified by arrows).
#Text=The colour map indicates out-ofplane orientations of grains.
#Text=Scale bar, 100 m m. (b) Higher magnification SEM image of the boxed region in a illustrating mixed intergranular and transgranular fracture along the main crack.
#Text=Scale bar, 10 m m.
#Text=Figure 2 | Two categories of secondary cracks.
#Text=SEM and EBSD analysis of a representative (a c) single-GB and (d f) multi-GB crack.
#Text=(a, d) SEM micrographs with (b, e) overlaid EBSD maps are used to identify cracked and connected, non-cracked, GBs in secondary cracks.
#Text=To assess the statistical significance of this conclusion, we compare the fraction of S 3 CTBs in single-GB cracks with their fraction in the microstructure as a whole (Supplementary Note 1).

#Text=Had cracks initiated at any GB in the microstructure with equal likelihood, then the probability or ' P-value' of finding 13 S 3 CTBs at 33 single-GBs cracks would be o 0.05 (Supplementary Table 1).
#Text=Thus, we conclude that S 3 CTBs are indeed preferential crack initiation sites.
#Text=To unambiguously identify the initiation site of the primary crack, we performed an in situ tensile test on a thin (30 m m) sample with through-thickness grains.
#Text=All the GBs are visible on the surface of this sample and no secondary cracks are observed.

#Text=The main crack initiates along a S 3 and a S 9 boundary, in agreement with the results reported in Fig. 3, and then quickly propagates across the sample (Supplementary Movie 1 and Supplementary Fig. 3).
#Text=To determine GB susceptibility to crack propagation, we analysed multi-GB cracks using a similar procedure to that used for crack initiation.
#Text=If a specific GB type is crack-propagation resistant, we expect it to occur less frequently in multi-GB cracks than in the microstructure as a whole.
#Text=Figure 3b shows that 52 out of 66 (B 79%) cracked GBs in multi-GB cracks are general GBs, whereas only 14 (B 21%) are low-S and 8 (B 12%) are S 3 CTBs.

#Text=Interestingly, the incidence of low-S GBs in multi-GB cracks is consistent with the frequency of crack initiation at low-S GBs, suggesting that when low-S GBs do appear in multi-GB cracks, it is likely that they are the initiation sites.
#Text=Indeed, only 3 out of 66 multi-GB cracks contain more than one low-S GB.
#Text=We also analyse the GB junctions at the tips of secondary cracks (both in single-and multi-GB cracks) to assess the role of GB connectivity in crack propagation.
#Text=We categorize these junctions according to the number of low-S boundaries among the boundaries ahead of the crack tip: zero, one or two.

#Text=Figure 3c compares the types of GB junctions found at the crack tips of all 99 secondary cracks from the thicker sample with their expected occurrence in the microstructure as a whole (Supplementary Note 2).
#Text=In Inconel 725, they are weak against crack initiation and strong against crack propagation.
#Text=Instead, they both terminate in short intragranular cracks.

#Text=Indeed, hydrogen is well known to enhance dislocation activity 25,26 and to give rise to much higher dislocation densities than would be expected based on the uniform plastic strain applied$^{27}$.
#Text=The results, shown in Fig. 5, indicate that cracks initiating on CTBs are often inclined at B 60 ° to the tensile axis.

#Text=The fact that crack initiation occurs mostly at CTBs oriented at oblique angles with respect to the tensile axis, as seen in Fig. 5, shows that some slip along the boundary is necessary before conditions favouring decohesion are established.
#Text=Another plasticity mechanism that may play a role in crack initiation is slip transmission and plastic flow localization.

#Text=Previous studies have pointed to the importance of the orientation of slip systems relative to the GB plane in controlling susceptibility to integranular cracking$^{37-39}$. In these studies, favourably oriented slip channels impinging on GBs cause incorporation of dislocations directly into the boundary plane.
#Text=CTBs transmit dislocations on some slip systems easily, but constitute strong barriers to dislocation motion on others$^{29}$.
#Text=Dislocations that are not transmitted may remain trapped at the CTB plane.
#Text=Because CTB planes are dislocation glide planes in Inconel 725, we expect that trapped dislocations are able to glide more easily within CTBs than dislocations trapped in general GBs.

#Text=The high mobility of trapped dislocations at CTBs may promote the formation of dislocation substructures in the boundary plane, similar to those formed by cyclic loading within persistent slip bands$^{21}$.
#Text=It has been suggested that g 0 precipitates, which are present in Inconel 725 (ref. 40), may also play a role in crack initiation on S 3 CTBs$^{41}$.
#Text=The effect of dislocation plasticity on crack initiation may be far more complex when multiple cracks initiate along the same GB, as shown in Fig.

#Text=Thus, failure at such boundaries is promoted predominantly by tension, rather than shearing, and classical H-induced decohesion (that is, without the influence of slip along the boundary plane) may play a more significant role in fracture.
#Text=Three dogbone-shaped specimens with a gage length of 15 mm and width of 1.7 mm were cut out using electrical discharge machining.
#Text=They were mechanically ground to 30 and 45 m m thickness and polished on both sides to 0.04 m m with a colloidal silica suspension.
#Text=After polishing, two samples were cathodically charged with hydrogen (H) for 12 h at a current density of 100 mA cm-2 in 1 N H$_{2}$SO$_{4}$. The third sample was tested with no hydrogen.
#Text=Under these conditions, the H-charging depth is expected to be on the order of B 10 m m.
#Text=Before testing, the sample microstructure was characterized by EBSD using a step size of 2 m m with a Philips XL30 SEM.
#Text=The GB network and GB character distribution were analysed using MTex 3.4.1 in Matlab 2013b.
